title: Ceanothus pauciflorus
text:
Ceanothus pauciflorus, known by the common name Mojave ceanothus, is a species of flowering <a href="shrub">shrub</a> in the <a href="buckthorn">buckthorn</a> family, <a href="Rhamnaceae">Rhamnaceae</a>. It is native to the <a href="Southwestern%20United%20States">Southwestern United States</a> (<a href="Arizona">Arizona</a>, <a href="California">California</a>, <a href="New%20Mexico">New Mexico</a>, <a href="Texas">Texas</a>, and <a href="Utah">Utah</a>) and <a href="Mexico">Mexico</a>, where it grows primarily in <a href="shrubland">shrubland</a> communities at moderate to high elevations. It is characterized by oppositely arranged leaves, corky stipules and white flowers. It was formerly known as Ceanothus greggii.
Description.
"Ceanothus pauciflorus" is a many-branched shrub with woody parts that are gray in color and somewhat woolly. The flowers bloom in spring. Blooms are considered highly fragrant. "C. pauciflorus" is eagerly browsed by <a href="livestock">livestock</a> and wild <a href="ungulate">ungulate</a>s such as <a href="mule%20deer">mule deer</a> and <a href="desert%20bighorn%20sheep">desert bighorn sheep</a>.
Morphology.
This species is a <a href="shrub">shrub</a>, around 0.2 to 4 m tall. The <a href="Trunk%20%28botany%29">stem</a> is ascending to erect, and generally branches from at or near the base. The <a href="Twig">twigs</a> are colored a pale gray to more or less white, and are densely <a href="Trichome">puberulent</a> to short-tomentose. The <a href="evergreen">evergreen</a> leaves are arranged oppositely, on a <a href="Petiole%20%28botany%29">petiole</a> 1 to 3 mm long, and with a <a href="Leaf%23Morphology">leaf blade</a> 5 to 20 mm long by 3 to 19 mm wide. The adaxial surface of the leaf is concave, colored gray-green to yellow-green, and puberulent, becoming glabrous (smooth) in age. The abaxial surface of the leaf is convex, colored gray-green, and is glabrous or has short, curly hairs. The tip of the leaf is generally shaped acute to obtuse. The margins of the leaf may have teeth. The stipule is a knob-like structure.
The <a href="inflorescence">inflorescence</a> is a small (less than 2 cm long) cluster of many white <a href="flower">flower</a>s on short lateral branches. The <a href="fruit">fruit</a> is a horned capsule a few millimeters wide which bursts explosively to expel the three seeds inside, which require thermal <a href="Scarification%20%28botany%29">scarification</a> from <a href="wildfire">wildfire</a> before they can <a href="germination">germinate</a>.
Taxonomy.
This species is a member of the "Ceanothus" <a href="subgenus">subgenus</a> "Cerastes".
Classification.
This species was originally discovered to science by Spanish botanists <a href="Mart%C3%ADn%20Sess%C3%A9%20y%20Lacasta">Martín Sessé y Lacasta</a> and <a href="Jos%C3%A9%20Mariano%20Moci%C3%B1o">José Mariano Mociño</a> on an expedition to western Mexico in 1790 to 1791. It was later described as "Ceanothus pauciflorus" by <a href="Augustin%20Pyramus%20de%20Candolle">Augustin Pyramus de Candolle</a> in 1825, based off of the illustrations made by Sessé and Mociño expedition. Sessé and Mociño also collected a flowering specimen of "Ceanothus", later determined to be "Ceanothus pauciflorus."
Because "Ceanothus pauciflorus" was the first description of the plant, subsequent descriptions were reduced to synonyms. It was named by <a href="Asa%20Gray">Asa Gray</a> of <a href="Harvard%20University">Harvard University</a> in 1853 as "Ceanothus greggii" in honor of its collector, <a href="Josiah%20Gregg">Josiah Gregg</a>, who found the plant in 1847 at the site of the <a href="Battle%20of%20Buena%20Vista">Battle of Buena Vista</a> in the Mexican state of <a href="Coahuila">Coahuila</a> during the <a href="Mexican%E2%80%93American%20War">Mexican–American War</a>. <a href="Edward%20Lee%20Greene">Edward Lee Greene</a> named it as "Ceanothus vestitus", but recent taxonomic analysis finds that "C. vestitus" does not have enough morphological evidence to warrant a separate taxon from "C. pauciflorus".
Distribution and habitat.
"Ceanothus pauciflorus" is widely distributed throughout the <a href="southwestern%20United%20States">southwestern United States</a> and northern <a href="Mexico">Mexico</a>. In the United States, it is found in the states of <a href="Arizona">Arizona</a>, <a href="California">California</a>, <a href="Nevada">Nevada</a>, <a href="New%20Mexico">New Mexico</a>, <a href="Texas">Texas</a>, and <a href="Utah">Utah</a>. It is widely distributed in Mexico, found from <a href="Baja%20California">Baja California</a> and <a href="Coahuila">Coahuila</a> south to <a href="Oaxaca">Oaxaca</a>. In Baja California, it is found from the Sierra Juarez to the <a href="Sierra%20de%20La%20Asamblea">Sierra de la Asamblea</a>. However, it is replaced in a portion of its range in California and Baja California with a close relative, "<a href="Ceanothus%20perplexans">Ceanothus perplexans</a>". This species is found on a variety of habitats over its wide distribution, although it is almost always found in shrub-dominated communities like <a href="chaparral">chaparral</a> and matorral at moderate to high elevations (550 to 2600 m).
